qas.question: What year was peripheral pattern theory developed?
Whose suggestion prompted the development of peripheral pattern theory?
What did DC Sinclair and G Weddell propose a property of all skin fiber endings is?
What does the gate control theory specify the diameter of which is responsible for the amount of pain sensation?
Why were peripheral pattern theory and gate control theory left behind?

answers.text: superseded by more modern theories of pain

qas.question: What did DC Sinclair develop in 1934?
What did DC Weddell and G Sinclair develop?
What is the 1934 peripheral pattern theory based on?
What did Ronald Wall and Patrick Melzack introduce?

context: In <a0_0>1955<a0_0/>, DC Sinclair and G Weddell developed <b5_0><b6_0>peripheral pattern theory<b6_0/><b5_0/>, based on a 1934 <b7_0>suggestion by <a1_0>John Paul Nafe<b7_0/><a1_0/>. They proposed that all skin fiber endings (with the exception of those innervating hair cells) are <a2_0>identical<a2_0/>, and that pain is produced by intense stimulation of these fibers. Another 20th-century theory was <b9_0>gate control theory<b9_0/>, introduced by Ronald Melzack and Patrick Wall in the 1965 Science article <b8_0>"Pain Mechanisms: A New Theory"<b8_0/>. The authors proposed that both thin (pain) and large diameter (touch, pressure, vibration) <a3_0>nerve fibers<a3_0/> carry information from the site of injury to two destinations in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord, and that the more large fiber activity relative to thin fiber activity at the inhibitory cell, the less pain is felt. Both peripheral pattern theory and gate control theory have been <a4_0>superseded by more modern theories of pain<a4_0/>[citation needed].
